Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Bryan_Beus i can help you document addressindex/timestampindex/unspentindex if you need help

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Bryan_Beus please add this to your notes: "When enabling any of these indexes, if you already have a partially synced chain, you will need to delete all blockchain data and do a fresh sync with those params. Simply trying to add those indexes with -reindex will not work correctly"

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that should really be in some documentation somewhere

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: very recent BTC core has a way to partially update indexes, maybe one day we can merge that, but it might be hard

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
Fantastic, thank you.

Yes, I was worried about starting this up myself. Thought it might trigger some long process.

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: I would only worry about it if we start getting complaints from users trying to use it.

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: Will you be around for a while, @dukeleto ?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it is a long process, because you basically have to resync the whole chain with new params

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Bryan_Beus I will be around for a bit

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: for a small asset chain, it's not a big deal. But enabling them on a KMD node is potentially many hours or days

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: depending on your internet and hardware

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: phew, glad I didn't try it.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Bryan_Beus when I helped write `getsnapshot` I used the AXO ac, because it was the smallest

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and I could resync that chain completely with new params, in a few seconds

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: Interesting.

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: Okay, let me take a look at some of these commands here.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: https://dexstats.info/richlist.php?asset=KMD

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: all the richlists on dexstats use `getsnapshot` which relies on those indexes, in case you need an example

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: without the indexes, some operations are drastically infeasible or impossible to do in a reasonable time. The indexes are like database indexes, which make common operations fast so you can get the data you want

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: Right, it makes sense.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the unspent index keeps track of every address and all of it's unspent utxo amounts in a fast and easy-to-access way. Without that, you have to do very very slow bruteforce searches to get the data

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: I'm typing on this as we speak. Thank you very much.

Content: webworker01 mentioned there's a config file that you can add this to, to make it a default launch parameter.

Content: yup

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: komodo.conf

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: great

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it already has txindex=1 by default

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: so you can add more indexes, and then you don't have to type them on the command line

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: so, you just add a line ``addressindex=1`` anywhere in the file?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: yes

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: https://github.com/jl777/komodo#create-komodoconf

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: maybe we can add docs to the readme right there, to tell people they can add them in right there

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's a nice place to tell people, because if you are reading that, you are probably setting up a kmd node for the first time on a certain machine, and it's nice to know to enable the other indexes then, versus later and having to resync the whole chain

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
Perhaps.

I'm putting it under the ``AddressIndex`` section in the Komodo API for now. I'm not working on the GitHub readme, for now.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: sounds good, it's an advanced option that average folks won't need anyway

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
So, you mentioned that if your blockchain data is only partially downloaded, you have to delete all blockchain data and start from scratch.

What if your blockchain is fully downloaded? Can you add `-addressindex=1` and get a positive result?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: nope

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: because even if it's 100% synced, you must stop and restart

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: Okay, so you have to resync, no matter what.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: yes, as far as I know. Weird errors happened for me when I tried to do that, before I knew this

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: James suggested that adding those params later on, doesn't work, and he was right

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Bryan_Beus and to be even more clear, I think if you add or subtract any index CLI params, you might need to blow away blockchain data

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: like, if you had addressindex but not spentindex, and then wanted to add it

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: best practice, imho, would be to add all the index options, if you need any

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: great, adding that in

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: Which folder is the blockchain data in, that should be deleted?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that needs it's own little faq or whatever

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's ~/.komodo on unixy systems, which also has wallet.dat, so people need to be careful

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: Yes, I'll probably try to add that in.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: ~/Library/Application Support/Komodo on mac

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i don't do windows üòÉ

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: me neither, we won't worry about it for now

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: what's the name of the file to delete?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I often run this command to do that: `rm -rf  blocks chainstate notarisations komodostate komodostate.ind`

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: make sure to tell people not to typo on that command

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: heh. yes.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I once used `rm -rf  blocks chainstate notarisations komodostate*` and accidentally put a space between the last word and *

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: thankfully I am crazy and backup my wallet.dat with git, otherwise it would be gone

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: which is why I listed both files above. I am not even sure if they are needed to get rid of, but I think it can confuse kmd to have that state file around that doesn't correspond to anything anymore

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: yesh

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's not user-friendly to blow away the blockchain data but not your wallet.dat, for sure

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: but average users probably shouldn't be doing that anyway. maybe we can have a simple script like `clear_blockchain_data.sh` that we can tell people to use

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: That would be a good idea, actually.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I wouldn't tell average  windows users to do the above steps, they definitely need a GUI/script or you will have lots of wallet.dat's deleted, most probably

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
@dukeleto take a look at this:
Anything in the `<== ==>` is a note for the team, to be added later. You can ignore it.

```
Coin Daemon Maintenance and Parameters
======================================

<==Gcharang: we need to add this section above in the index ==>

Manually deleting blockchain data
---------------------------------
Sometimes it is necessary to manually delete all blockchain data. This will trigger a full resync of the blockchain.

Users should exercise caution not to delete the ``wallet.dat`` file during this procedure. We recommend that the user make frequent backups of the ``wallet.dat`` file, especially before deleting files from the application directory.

The following files should be deleted:

::
  ``blocks``
  ``chainstate``
  ``notarisations``
  ``komodostate``
  ``komodostate.ind``

Default file locations:
::
    MacOS: ``~/Library/Application Support/Komodo``
    GNU/Linux: ``~/.komodo``
    Windows: <<==need this==>

-addressindex
-------------
The ``addressindex`` is a parameter that is executed at run time. The command instructs a KMD-based coin daemon to make a full index of all addresses and balances. It is commonly used in web-based blockchain explorers for rapid search across the entire blockchain history.

When utilizing this command the synced blockchain data should be deleted to allow for a full resync. The user may need to manually delete the blockchain data before executing the command <==link to manual deletion instructions above==>.

The ``-reindex`` command is not a viable alternative method for resyncing the blockchain.

Usage:

To initiate the ``addressindex`` command at runtime, include ``-addressindex=1`` as a parameter.

::

  ``./komodod -addressindex=1``

To set the ``addressindex`` feature as a default parameter, include the parameter in the ``komodo.conf`` configuration file.

::

  ``addressindex=1``
```
